results.title: Borrowed faces
results.brief_description: Covers the audition process at the 1979 Colorado Shakespeare Festival from the viewpoints of the actors and directors. The actors’ feelings about acting, about themselves and the roles they play are examined, as well as how they handle rejections; the directors talk about how they decide which actors to cast in which roles. The final scene shows the successful actors playing the roles for which they auditioned.

results.title: Two laws. Part 2: Welfare times
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 2 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. Describes the life of the Borroloola community under the welfare system of the 1950s to the present day. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: St Barbe of the trees
results.creator_credit: Barrie Oldfield and M B Oldfield and Sons
results.brief_description: Presents 92 year-old Richard St Barbe Baker, the man who founded the international movement “Men of the Trees” in 1922, talking about trees: their life-giving qualities, the threats to them from disease and overfelling; and the need to plant for our lives. The first half of the film is scientific in approach while the second half becomes more lyrical with St Barbe reciting his favourite tree poems.

results.title: What am I bid for the tree?
results.creator_credit: Barrie Oldfield and Oldfield and Sons
results.brief_description: A satirical approach to the value of trees. Actor, James Bailey, by taking on various guises - teacher, philosopher, auctioneer, architect - tries to inform an uninterested audience of the many uses of the tree. Filmed at Wungong Brook, Western Australia - a film for Arbor Day. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Looking at the wild
results.brief_description: Harry Butler shows aspiring naturalists some of the simpler but fundamental techniques necessary to enjoy more fully a natural bush environment. Harry comments on the dress and basic equipment; demonstrates simple pit-traps and more complex fauna traps; and stresses the need for interest and enquiry in the natural bush environment.

results.title: Twins: matching genes
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the progress made since 1936 when Dr Norma Ford Walker established a Twin Register: explains how fraternal and identical twins develop; shows a close examination of the placentas of twins; observes the behaviour of a set of identical twins; and concludes with a pair of identical twins separated shortly after birth reminiscing about their discovery of each other after twenty-four years. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Whales that wouldn't die
results.creator_credit: Frank Christopher, Susan K Pollock and KPBS (Television station : San Diego, Calif.)
results.brief_description: Studies the characteristics, population density and habitats of the Grey Whale. Discusses the history of whaling, its particular effect on the Grey Whale, and the animal’s future prospects for survival.

results.title: Mister Prime Minister: Joseph Benedict Chifley
results.brief_description: The life and political career of J.B. Chifley, Prime Minister of Australia 1945-1949. Covers his early life and rise through the ranks of the ALP; notes the record amount of legislation passed furing his term of office, and presents interviews with associates. Narrated by Roger Climpson. Suitable for secondary level.
